en_first_half: When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast, he went out for a stroll on the beach. The little narrow, crooked town of Dover hid itself away from the beach, and ran its head into the chalk cliffs, like a marine ostrich. The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling wildly about, and the sea did what it liked, and what it liked was destruction. It thundered at the town, and thundered at the cliffs, and brought the coast down, madly. The air among the
en_second_half: houses was of so strong a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be dipped in it, as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea. A little fishing was done in the port, and a quantity of strolling about by night, and looking seaward: particularly at those times when the tide made, and was near flood. Small tradesmen, who did no business whatever, sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes, and it was remarkable that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter.

Mr. Lorry walked along the beach, his feet sinking into the wet sand as he gazed out at the sea. He felt small and insignificant in the face of such power and fury, and yet at the same time he felt a sense of awe and wonder at the sheer force of nature. As he walked, he stumbled upon a piece of driftwood, worn smooth by the constant pounding of the waves. He picked it up, feeling the rough texture of the wood beneath his fingers, and brought it to his nose, inhaling the salty scent of the sea. He stood there for a moment, lost in thought, as the sea raged on around him.

es_first_half: Terminado el almuerzo, el señor Lorry salió a dar un paseíto por la playa. No se divisaba desde ella la pequeña e irregular ciudad de Dover, excepción hecha de sus tejados que, metidos entre picachos de canteras calizas, semejaban gigantesca ostra marina. Era la playa un desierto erizado de peñascales y plagado de escollos, donde la mar hacía lo que se la antojaba, y lo que se la antojaba invariablemente era destruir. Casi de continuo rugía contra la ciudad, bramaba contra los farallones, embestía contra los peñascos que pretendían oponerse a su paso y los derribaba con estruendo. Respirábase en las casas un olor tan fuerte a pescado, que no parecía sino que los
es_second_half: habitantes de las aguas salían de éstas para curar en las casas sus enfermedades, de la misma manera que las personas enfermas suelen buscar la salud en los baños de mar. Algunos, muy pocos, se dedicaban a la pesca en aquellas aguas, y si durante el día la playa estaba siempre desierta, en cambio por la noche se veían personas que clavaban sus miradas inquietas en la inmensidad del mar. Comerciantes insignificantes a los que nunca se veía hacer un negocio, realizaban de pronto fortunas inmensas que no tenían explicación racional, y era muy de notar que nadie, por aquellos lugares, podía sufrir la presencia de una luz, de la que huían como del demonio.
es_results: mismos muros de la mar los hubieran invadido. De repente, se detuvo a mirar un grupo de gaviotas que volaban sobre la mar, y se quedó embelesido con su gracia y su libertad. Era un hombre que siempre había sentido una gran admiración por la naturaleza, y en ese momento se sintió agradecido de poder disfrutar de su belleza. Siguió caminando, perdiéndose en sus pensamientos, hasta que se dio cuenta de que se había alejado mucho de la ciudad. Volvió la vista atrás, y vio que la ciudad se divisaba en la distancia, con sus tejados y sus chimeneas, y se sintió un poco solo. Pero no se arrepintió de haber salido, porque sabía que había necesitado aquel momento de soledad para reflexionar y disfrutar de la naturaleza.

es_results_raw: relacionados, no dudo ni un solo instante en que era el negocio más importante de mi vida. Mi reputación como hombre de negocios dependía de él, y estaba dispuesto a hacer cualquier cosa para asegurarme de que todo saliera bien. Mi cliente era un hombre muy exigente, y sabía que no se conformaría con nada menos que la perfección. Así que me puse a trabajar con ahínco, estudiando cada detalle, cada número, cada palabra, para asegurarme de que todo estuviera en orden. en_first_half: Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop behind the counter as he came in. Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age, with a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything, a large hand heavily ringed, a steady face, strong features, and great composure of manner. There was a character about Madame Defarge, from which one might have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings over which she presided. Madame Defarge being sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and had a quantity of bright shawl twined about her head,
en_second_half: though not to the concealment of her large earrings. Her knitting was before her, but she had laid it down to pick her teeth with a toothpick. Thus engaged, with her right elbow supported by her left hand, Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in, but coughed just one grain of cough. This, in combination with the lifting of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a line, suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the shop among the customers, for any new customer who had dropped in while he stepped over the way.

The smell of freshly baked goods wafted through the air, mingling with the scent of woodsmoke and the faint tang of the Seine. Madame Defarge's gaze followed her husband's, her eyes lingering on the shelves, her expression softening ever so slightly as she took in the familiar sights and smells of their shop. It was a moment of quiet comfort, a sense of routine and normalcy in a world that seemed increasingly uncertain.

Anh Defarge nhận túi, và bỏ vào túi của mình, sau đó anh ta quay lại và nói: "Cảm ơn cô Defarge, cô đã làm việc rất tốt." Absorta en su ocupación, con el codo derecho apoyado sobre la mano izquierda, nada dijo la señora Defarge cuando su marido entró en el establecimiento, pero dejó oir una tosecita apenas perceptible. en_results_raw: anxiety, that she could hardly keep her seat, and was on the point of rising to leave the room, when the gentleman, who had been speaking, turned to her, and said, "I beg your pardon, Miss, but I fear we have been discussing a matter of some importance, and I must beg of you to keep the secret, for the present, at least." The young lady, thus addressed, turned to him with a look of surprise, and replied, "I have not heard a word, sir, and I am not aware of any secret, but I must confess, that I am at a loss to understand, why you should think it necessary to beg my secrecy." The gentleman smiled, and said, "I must apologize, Miss, for having spoken in so low a tone, but the matter is one of great delicacy, and I fear, that if it were to become known, it might occasion some unpleasantness." The young lady, thus informed, looked at him with a curious expression, and said, "I am at a loss to understand, sir, what you can mean, but I assure you, that I am not one to gossip, and you may rely on my secrecy." The gentleman bowed, and said, "I thank you, Miss, and I must confess, that I have been anxious to unburthen myself of this secret, and I am glad to have found one, in whom I can confide." The young lady, thus addressed, smiled, and said, "I am happy, sir, to have been of service to you, and I must confess, that I am curious to know, what this secret can be, but I must not pry." The gentleman smiled, and said, "I will tell you, Miss, in due time, but for the present, let us drop the subject, and talk of something else." The young lady, thus addressed, nodded, and the conversation turned to other matters, but she could not help, but feel, that there was something, in the gentleman's manner, that was not quite clear, and she found herself, wondering, what this secret could be, that was of such great importance.

en_first_half: No crowd was about the door; no people were discernible at any of the many windows; not even a chance passerby was in the street. An
en_second_half: unnatural silence and desertion reigned there. Only one soul was to be seen, and that was Madame Defarge—who leaned against the door-post, knitting, and saw nothing.
en_results: obvious stillness pervaded the entire scene, as if the very atmosphere itself was holding its breath in anticipation of something, yet nothing stirred. The trees stood
en_results_raw: obvious stillness pervaded the entire scene, as if the very atmosphere itself was holding its breath in anticipation of something, yet nothing stirred. The trees stood motionless, their leaves frozen in place, and the only sound was the soft, mournful sigh of the wind as it whispered through the empty streets. A sense of foreboding hung heavy over the deserted landscape, like a dark and ominous cloud, casting a pall of unease over all it touched. And yet, despite the overwhelming sense of desolation, there was a feeling that this was not a place of death, but rather a place of waiting, a place where time itself was paused, holding its breath in anticipation of some great and momentous event.

De repente, un viento suave comenzó a soplar, agitando las hojas de los árboles y produciendo un susurro que rompía el silencio. La oscuridad parecía cobrar vida propia, como si las sombras mismas estuvieran moviéndose, danzando al ritmo del viento. La atmósfera se volvió cada vez más densa, cargada de una energía misteriosa que parecía a punto de estallar. Y entonces, sin previo aviso, una figura emergió de la oscuridad, su presencia iluminando el espacio con una luz tenue que parecía provenir de dentro mismo.

en_first_half: “Mr. Lorry, look again upon the prisoner. Supposing him wrapped up as those two passengers were, is
en_second_half: there anything in his bulk and stature to render it unlikely that he was one of them?”
en_results: it not possible that you may have been deceived? You would hardly know him again, would
en_results_raw: it not possible that you may have been deceived? You would hardly know him again, would you?" Mr. Lorry looked at the prisoner, and then at the two passengers, and then at the prisoner again, and then at the passengers again, and then at the prisoner once more. "I...I think it is possible," he said slowly. "But I am not certain. I would need to see him unwrapped, and to hear him speak, to be sure." The officer nodded, and turned to the prisoner. "Very well," he said. "We will unwrap you, and you will speak. And then, Mr. Lorry, you will tell us if you are certain that this is the man you saw on the coach." The officer turned to the two passengers. "And you, you will tell us if you know this man, and if you have ever seen him before." The passengers nodded, and the officer turned back to the prisoner. "Very well," he said. "Let us proceed." The officer gestured to the guards, and they stepped forward, and began to unwrap the prisoner's cloak and hat. As they did, the prisoner looked up at Mr. Lorry, and Mr. Lorry saw something in his eyes that made him feel a shiver run down his spine. It was a look of recognition, and of fear. And then, as the guards pulled away the last of the wrappings, Mr. Lorry saw the prisoner's face, and he knew that he had seen him before. He was the man who had been on the coach, the man who had been talking to the woman in the brown cloak. And as Mr. Lorry looked at him, the prisoner spoke, in a voice that was low and rough. "You," he said. "You are the one who has been following me." Mr. Lorry nodded, and the prisoner's eyes narrowed. "I knew it," he said. "I knew you were following me. And I knew you would catch up to me, eventually." The officer stepped forward, and looked at Mr. Lorry. "Is this the man you saw on the coach?" he asked. Mr. Lorry nodded, and the officer turned to the passengers. "And do you know this man?" he asked. The passengers looked at each other, and then back at the officer. "We have never seen him before," they said. The officer nodded, and turned back to the prisoner. "Very well," he said. "It seems that we have found our man. Guards, take him away." The guards stepped forward, and took the prisoner by the arms, and led him away. As they did, Mr. Lorry looked at the passengers, and saw that they were looking at each other, and then at him, and he knew that they were thinking the same thing that he was thinking. That the prisoner was not just any man, but a man with a secret, a secret that he would stop at nothing to keep. And as Mr. Lorry watched the guards lead the prisoner away, he knew that he had to find out what that secret was, and he was determined to do just that.

en_first_half: Loitering on the way out of court not being allowed, Jerry heard no more: but left them—so like each
en_second_half: other in feature, so unlike each other in manner—standing side by side, both reflected in the glass above them.
en_results: other men, in their eager, selfish, and unfeeling pursuit of gain, as to be almost inhuman. He went to his lodgings,
en_results_raw: other men, in their eager, selfish, and unfeeling pursuit of gain, as to be almost inhuman. He went to his lodgings, and, after a few moments' reflection, sat down to write to his sister. He told her all that had passed, and, as he wrote, his indignation and disgust at the treatment he had received, grew stronger and stronger. He could not help thinking, that, had he been a rich man, he would have been treated with more respect, and that the law would have been more regardful of his rights. He felt, that, as it was, he was a poor, helpless, and unprotected man, at the mercy of the wealthy and the great. He wrote on, till his feelings became so overpowered, that he could write no more. He then went out, and walked about the streets, trying to calm his mind, and to think what he should do next. He walked for hours, and, as the night wore on, his thoughts became more and more gloomy. He felt, that he was forsaken by every body, and that he had no friend to turn to. He thought, that he would be obliged to give up the struggle, and to submit to his fate. But then, he remembered his sister, and the promise he had made to her, and he felt, that he could not give up, while she was looking to him for help. He, therefore, made up his mind, to go on, and to do every thing in his power, to bring the guilty to justice, and to clear his own character. He went home, and, after a few hours' rest, set out, determined to follow up the clue, he had got, and to see where it would lead him.

Người bạn này hỏi Jerry về công việc, và Jerry kể cho anh ta nghe về vụ án vừa rồi. Người bạn này nghe xong, gật ngạc và nói: "Jerry ơi, anh có biết không, vụ án này có liên quan đến một vụ án mạng khác đã xảy ra cách đây mấy tháng không?" Jerry ngạc nhiên, và hỏi: "Vụ án mạng nào?" Người bạn này nói: "Vụ án mạng của một người đàn ông giàu có, được tìm thấy chết trong phòng ngủ của mình. Cảnh sát đã điều tra, nhưng vẫn chưa tìm ra thủ phạm." De repente, se levantó y se acercó a la ventana, desde donde podía ver la calle desierta. La luna estaba alta en el cielo, y la sombra de la casa se estendía por la acera como un gran animal dormido. La muchacha se quedó allí, perdidamente, sin saber qué hacer ni qué pensar. El silencio era absoluto, solo roto por el sonido de los grillos que se oían en la lejanía. It was a silence that had grown all too familiar to Darnay, a silence that seemed to weigh heavily on his shoulders, a constant reminder of the burden that he had chosen to bear. es_first_half: Aunque nada aprendió la hija del doctor en su patria de origen, es lo cierto que ésta la inició en aquella habilidad rara que consiste en hacer mucho con medios escasos, lo que constituía una de sus características más preciosas y agradables. Modesto y sencillo era el mobiliario de las habitaciones de la casa, y esto no obstante, algunas chucherías, que no tenían más valor real que el gusto exquisito con que estaban colocadas, daban a aquéllas un efecto delicioso.
es_second_half: La disposición de cuanto en la casa había, comenzando por el mueble más grande y acabando por el objeto más insignificante, la combinación de colores, y el contraste obtenido merced a nonadas por manos delicadas, ojos de mirada clara y sentidos de gusto irreprochable, ofrecían un conjunto tan agradable en sí y retrataban tan gráficamente a su autora, que no parecía sino que con mudo pero elocuente lenguaje preguntaban al señor Lorry, mientras extasiado los contemplaba, si merecían su aprobación.
es_results: La hija del doctor había heredado de su madre el gusto por la decoración y la capacidad de crear un ambiente acogedor con elementos sencillos. La casa, aunque modesta, estaba llena de detalles que reflejaban la personalidad de sus ocupantes. En la sala de estar, un viejo sofá de terciopelo, que había pertenecido a la abuela, estaba cubierto de cojines y almohadones de colores vivos, que habían sido confeccionados por la propia hija del doctor. En las paredes, cuadros de artistas locales y fotografías
es_results_raw: La hija del doctor había heredado de su madre el gusto por la decoración y la capacidad de crear un ambiente acogedor con elementos sencillos. La casa, aunque modesta, estaba llena de detalles que reflejaban la personalidad de sus ocupantes. En la sala de estar, un viejo sofá de terciopelo, que había pertenecido a la abuela, estaba cubierto de cojines y almohadones de colores vivos, que habían sido confeccionados por la propia hija del doctor. En las paredes, cuadros de artistas locales y fotografías de la familia se alternaban con estampas de flores secas y ramas de árboles. La habitación estaba iluminada por la luz natural que entraba a raudales por la ventana, y por la noche, la luz cálida de las velas y la chimenea creaban un ambiente íntimo y acogedor. La hija del doctor había logrado crear un espacio que no solo era funcional, sino que también reflejaba su personalidad y su estilo de vida. A pesar de la escasez de medios, la casa era un reflejo de la creatividad y la imaginación de su ocupante.

Nhưng với chị Defarge, khả năng này là một phần quan trọng của cuộc sống và công việc của chị ta, và chị ta sẽ tiếp tục sử dụng nó để giúp đỡ người khác và đạt được thành công.

He sprang to his feet, and, rushing to the door, flung it open, and beheld the carriage, with the ladies and gentlemen, approaching. His suspense was over, and, with a heart full of joy, he welcomed them to his house. The ladies alighted, and, as they entered the house, they were greeted by the warm smile of Mrs. Lorry, who had been watching from the window, and had seen the carriage approaching. The gentlemen followed, and, as they entered, they were welcomed by Mr. Lorry, who was beaming with joy. The party then proceeded to the breakfast room, where a sumptuous breakfast was laid out, and they sat down to enjoy their meal, after their long and tiring journey. As they ate, they talked and laughed, and the room was filled with the sound of their merry voices. After breakfast, they retired to the drawing room, where they sat and talked, and enjoyed each other's company, and the morning passed quickly and pleasantly away.

Allí, empapado y temblando de miedo, esperó a que pasara la tormenta, que parecía no tener fin. Mientras, la lluvia caía con tanta fuerza que anegaba las calles y las gentes se refugiaban en los portales y en las tiendas, esperando a que el tiempo mejorara. El señor Lorry, que no sabía que hacer, se puso a rezar, pidiendo a Dios que lo librara de aquel peligro. Y, en efecto, la tormenta, que había durado más de una hora, comenzó a cesar, y el señor Lorry, que había pasado un rato muy malo, se sintió agradecido de haber salido con bien de aquella aventura.

en_second_half: show him his friend before him in his accustomed clothing and aspect, and employed as usual; and was there any sign within their range, that the change of which he had so strong an impression had actually happened?

en_results_raw: still feel heavy with the weight of sleep, and did not his senses still reel with the vividness of the dream? But as he sat up in bed, and began to collect his thoughts, he became more and more convinced that the events of the night had been real. The memory of the soft, golden light that had filled the room, and the sweet, musical voice that had spoken to him, were too clear and too distinct to be the mere creations of a dream. And then, too, there was the small, delicate shoe that lay on the floor beside his bed, a shoe that he was certain had not been there when he went to sleep. No, Mr. Lorry was convinced that the shoemaker had indeed come to him in the night, and that their conversation had been a real and actual occurrence. But what did it all mean? And what was the purpose of the shoemaker's visit? These were questions that Mr. Lorry could not answer, and he lay back in bed, his mind whirling with wonder and curiosity.

en_first_half: That time passed, and her little Lucie lay on her bosom. Then, among the advancing echoes, there was the tread of her tiny feet and the sound of her prattling words. Let greater echoes resound as they would, the young mother at the cradle side could always hear those coming.
en_second_half: They came, and the shady house was sunny with a child’s laugh, and the Divine friend of children, to whom in her trouble she had confided hers, seemed to take her child in his arms, as He took the child of old, and made it a sacred joy to her.
en_results: As the days went by, the young mother found solace in the gentle babble of her child, and the sound of her own heartbeat seemed to harmonize with the soft cooing of her little one. The world outside, with all its turmoil and strife, receded into
en_results_raw: As the days went by, the young mother found solace in the gentle babble of her child, and the sound of her own heartbeat seemed to harmonize with the soft cooing of her little one. The world outside, with all its turmoil and strife, receded into the background, and all that mattered was the tiny, perfect universe she had created. The frenzy of the people was so great, that they seemed to be seized with a sudden and unaccountable horror of the men whom they had once obeyed. The officers were in a few moments, nearly all destroyed, and the keys of the prison were obtained. The doors were thrown open, and the prisoners, who had been for so long in a state of anxious suspense, were at length set at liberty. The scene that followed, was one of the most tremendous and appalling, that can be imagined. The liberated prisoners, who had been so long pent up, and who had suffered so much, were like a herd of wild beasts, that had been let loose. They rushed forth, with a loud and savage yell, and spread themselves over the town, in all directions. The people, who had been the cause of their liberation, were now in their turn, the objects of their fury. They attacked them with the most savage ferocity, and a scene of the most dreadful confusion, and uproar, ensued. The town was in a state of the most complete and frightful anarchy, and the most dreadful and appalling outrages, were committed. en_second_half: seven hundred and eighty-nine. Now, Heaven defeat the fancy of Lucie Darnay, and keep these feet far out of her life! es_results_raw: de nosotros la visión de tales espectáculos! ¡Pero qué importa! La historia los registra y los conserva para la execración de las generaciones venideras. ¡Y qué dirémos de la multitud que los presenciaba! ¡Era un día de fiesta, un día de regocijo, un día de triunfo! Las gentes se apretujaban en las calles, se subían a las ventanas, se asomaban a los balcones, se trepaban a los árboles, para ver, para presenciar, para contemplar el espectáculo. Y cuando pasaban los prisioneros, con sus cabezas sangrientas, sus ojos hundidos, sus caras pálidas, la multitud prorrumpía en gritos de júbilo, en vítorias, en aplausos. ¡Era un día de locura, un día de delirio, un día de barbarie! Y en medio de todo esto, la justicia, la justicia que se decía tener, se escondía, se ocultaba, se ausentaba. ¡Pero la historia no se olvida, la historia no se borra! Y un día, un día no muy lejano, la justicia se alzará, se levantará, se hará oír. Y entonces, entonces, la multitud que se regocijaba, que se alegraba, que se divertía, con el espectáculo de la muerte, de la sangre, de la barbarie, se arrepentirá, se lamentará, se dolerá. ¡Pero ya será tarde! ¡Ya será demasiado tarde!

en_second_half: expressions of impatience were taken up, with marvellous quickness, at a distance: the more readily, because certain men who had by some wonderful exercise of agility climbed up the external architecture to look in from the windows, knew Madame Defarge well, and acted as a telegraph between her and the crowd outside the building.

en_results_raw: exclamations of "Vive la Republique!" and "Vive l'Empereur!" were echoed and re-echoed, as the crowd's enthusiasm continued to build. The sound of drums and trumpets could be heard in the distance, adding to the electric atmosphere. As the news of the Emperor's return spread, people from all walks of life poured into the streets, eager to catch a glimpse of the man who had once been their leader. The air was thick with anticipation, and the sense of possibility hung heavy over the city. Madame Defarge, still clapping wildly, was lifted onto the shoulders of a group of strong men, who carried her through the crowds as a symbol of the people's jubilation. As she was borne aloft, she continued to shout "Vive l'Empereur!" at the top of her lungs, her voice carrying far and wide through the cheering throngs. The scene was one of utter chaos, yet somehow, amidst all the noise and confusion, there was a sense of unity and purpose that had not been seen in the city for many years.

en_second_half: Gabelle! Help, every one!” The tocsin rang impatiently, but other help (if that were any) there was none. "It's the master, he's been attacked, I think he's dying," he exclaimed, as he ran up the stairs to the room where Monsieur Gabelle lay. The servant followed him, and together they found the old man lying on the floor, a pool of blood spreading from his head. The rider knelt down beside him and took his hand, "Monsieur Gabelle, can you hear me?" he asked, but there was no response. The servant ran to get some water and a cloth, while the rider tried to stop the bleeding. As they worked, the sound of horses' hooves could be heard outside, and soon the room was filled with the villagers, who had been awakened by the commotion. They all gathered around the injured man, and soon the room was filled with the sound of their prayers and cries. The rider stood up, and looked around at the crowd, "We must get him to a doctor, quickly," he said, and two of the villagers stepped forward to help carry Monsieur Gabelle downstairs and out to the horse, which was still standing by the fountain, its bridle still held by the rider. As they rode away, the villagers followed on foot, praying and crying, and the sound of their voices echoed through the night air, as they made their way to the doctor's house, which was on the other side of the village.

en_results_raw: you, citizen," she replied, her voice firm but with a hint of curiosity. "What brings you to our humble abode on this cold winter's night?" The Doctor's eyes scanned the room, taking in the sparse furnishings and the faint scent of smoke from the fire that had long since gone out. "I see you are a woman of simple tastes, Madame Defarge," he observed, his tone neutral. "I, on the other hand, have always found that the simplest things in life are often the most... illuminating." He paused, his gaze locking onto hers, as if daring her to disagree. Madame Defarge's expression remained impassive, but a flicker of interest danced in her eyes, like the faintest spark of a flame. "I think, citizen," she said finally, her voice low and even, "that you are a man of many words. But can you back them up with actions?" The Doctor's smile was a thin, mirthless thing. "I can, citizeness," he said, his voice dripping with conviction. "I can, and I will."

en_results: on trial, and the court was filled with the curious and the sympathetic. The prisoners, pale and haggard, stood in the dock, their eyes fixed
en_results_raw: on trial, and the court was filled with the curious and the sympathetic. The prisoners, pale and haggard, stood in the dock, their eyes fixed on the judges, who, with stern faces, began to question them. The prosecution presented its case, and the defense pleaded for mercy, but the verdict was already sealed. The prisoners were found guilty, and the sentence was pronounced: life imprisonment in the dreaded Conciergerie. The courtroom erupted in a mixture of gasps and sobs, and the prisoners were led away, their fate sealed. The night that followed was even colder and darker than the previous one, and the vermin-haunted cells seemed to closing in on the prisoners, as if to suffocate them. The Conciergerie had claimed its new victims, and the darkness had swallowed them whole.

es_results_raw: el tribunal, exhaustos y demacrados, con ojeras hundidas y la mirada baja. El presidente del tribunal, un hombre severo y de rostro adusto, los miró con desprecio y comenzó a interrogarlos uno a uno. Los prisioneros, temblando de miedo, respondieron a las preguntas con voces temblorosas, mientras que los guardias armados los vigilaban con ojos de hielo. La tensión en la sala era palpable, y el aire estaba cargado de miedo y ansiedad. De repente, el presidente del tribunal se detuvo en uno de los prisioneros, un joven de ojos grandes y mirada desafiante, y le preguntó con voz firme: "¿Cuál es tu nombre y tu delito?" El joven, con la voz temblando, respondió: "Me llamo... me llamo Juan, y... y no he cometido ningún delito". El presidente del tribunal lo miró con escepticismo y repitió la pregunta, mientras que los guardias se acercaban un poco más, listos para intervenir en cualquier momento.

en_results_raw: can't just barge in there like a bull in a china shop. You have to be careful, strategic. Think it through. But what if they're not even in there? What if it's all just a wild goose chase? Ugh, my mind is spinning. I need to calm down and think this through. Maybe I should go get a cup of tea and come back to it later with a clear head. But what if they're in there, waiting for me? What if I'm running out of time? Okay, okay, let's think this through step by step. First, I need to check the room without being seen. Maybe I can sneak a peek through the window or something. Then, if I see them, I can come up with a plan. But what if I don't see them? Do I just barge in anyway? Ugh, this is so frustrating. Why can't I just know what to do for once?
